immigration.q: How long does it take to get a green card?
immigration.a: Processing times vary depending on the type of application. Family-based green cards can take 8-33 months, while employment-based cases may take 1-3 years.

immigration.q: Can I work while my immigration case is pending?
immigration.a: In many cases, yes. You may be eligible for work authorization (EAD) while your case is pending.

immigration.q: What if I entered the U.S. illegally?
immigration.a: There may still be paths to legal status. Options include family-based petitions, asylum, or waivers.

immigration.q: How much do immigration lawyers charge?
immigration.a: We offer transparent flat fees for most immigration cases. Fees vary by case type but we always provide upfront pricing.

personalInjury.q: How much is my case worth?
personalInjury.a: Case values depend on factors like medical expenses, lost wages, pain and suffering, and permanent disabilities.

personalInjury.q: How long do I have to file a claim?
personalInjury.a: North Carolina has a 3-year statute of limitations for most personal injury cases.

personalInjury.q: What if I was partially at fault?
personalInjury.a: North Carolina follows contributory negligence rules. Even 1% fault can bar recovery, making legal representation crucial.

personalInjury.q: Do I have to go to court?
personalInjury.a: Most personal injury cases settle out of court, but we're prepared to go to trial if necessary.
